projects.name: Perfectly pixelated lampshade

tools.name: square punch
tools.purpose: to make paint chips into uniform squares

steps.instruction: Gather paint chips in your desired color palette, and use a square punch to make them a uniform shape and size.
steps.visual_description: Various colored paper squares and a square punch.

steps.instruction: Lay the squares facedown on a piece of cardboard one section at a time, and coat them with spray adhesive.
steps.visual_description: Squares laid out on cardboard, ready for adhesive.

steps.instruction: Begin applying the paint chips to the top, center section of the lampshade, and work your way down and around, being mindful of color placement.
steps.visual_description: A lampshade being covered with colorful squares.

steps.instruction: When you reach the bottom row, trim squares to fit the remaining space before adhering to the lampshade.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of squares being trimmed to fit the bottom edge of the lampshade.

projects.finished_product_description: A drum lampshade covered in a pixelated pattern of colorful squares.

diagram_descriptions: A close-up of a red rhino figurine on a white surface.
A white cup filled with pencils of various colors and patterns.
A red drum lampshade with a colorful, pixelated pattern of squares.
A stack of books, one yellow and one light blue, with a white electronic device on top.
A small inset photo showing colorful paper squares, a green square punch, and a bottle of spray adhesive next to a partially covered lampshade.

projects.name: The Ombré Effect

steps.instruction: Trim a large, gradient-style paint chip to a standard photo size such as 4x6 or 5x7 inches.
steps.visual_description: A paint chip being trimmed to a rectangular photo size.

steps.instruction: Find a photo on your computer, convert it to black and white, and adjust your settings to print to the appropriate page size.
steps.visual_description: A computer screen showing a photo editing software with a black and white image.

steps.instruction: Feed the paint chip into your ink-jet printer and print the photo.
steps.visual_description: An ink-jet printer printing an image onto a paint chip.

steps.instruction: For a colorful wall display, arrange the photos in vertical frames and hang as a set.
steps.visual_description: Two vertical frames, each containing three ombré effect photos, hanging on a wall as a set.

projects.finished_product_description: A wall display of framed photos with an ombré effect, created by printing photos onto gradient-style paint chips.

diagram_descriptions: Two tall, narrow frames hanging on a white wall. The left frame contains three vertically stacked images: the top image is a close-up of a person's face with a torn paper effect and a green gradient; the middle image is a gradient of green paint chips; the bottom image is a close-up of a child's face with a colorful gradient.

The right frame also contains three vertically stacked images: the top image is a photo of a woman holding a child with an orange gradient; the middle image is a black and white close-up of a child's face; the bottom image is a gradient of red paint chips.
A white vase filled with orange tulips is placed to the right of the frames.
A stack of two books sits on a white surface below the frames. A small red bird figurine is perched on top of the books.
The bottom left corner of the page shows the number '10' followed by 'Do It Yourself | Spring 2013'.

projects.name: A floral frenzy

steps.instruction: Fashion a colorful, eye-catching garland from pretty paper flowers.
steps.visual_description: A garland made of paper flowers.

steps.instruction: Feed bright-color paint chips through a flower-shape crafts punch to create floral cutouts.
steps.visual_description: A red flower-shaped punch with a cut-out flower shape next to it.

steps.instruction: To make it three-dimensional, use a crafts knife to make a small cut between each petal toward the center of the flower.
steps.visual_description: A close-up of a paper flower with small cuts made between the petals towards the center.

steps.instruction: Lightly score across each petal horizontally and fold up.
steps.visual_description: A paper flower with scored lines on each petal, and petals folded upwards.

steps.instruction: Cut two small slits in the center of each flower, and chain together by threading ribbon through the openings.
steps.visual_description: Three paper flowers (two orange, one yellow) chained together with orange ribbon. Each flower has two small slits in the center, and the ribbon is threaded through them.

tips: Use screw punch for clean holes
projects.finished_product_description: A garland of three-dimensional paper flowers made from paint chips, chained together with ribbon.

diagram_descriptions: A red flower-shaped craft punch with several cut-out paper flowers in orange and yellow, and a craft knife.
A light blue gift box wrapped with orange ribbon and decorated with three layered paper flowers (two orange, one yellow).

projects.name: Custom Paint Chip Tabletop

steps.instruction: Cut paint chips into uniform-size strips.
steps.visual_description: Paint chips cut into strips of varying colors.

steps.instruction: Arrange the strips on your tabletop as desired. To help jog your memory when adhering the strips, snap a picture or draw a diagram of the design.
steps.visual_description: Tabletop with colorful paint chip strips arranged in a herringbone pattern.

steps.instruction: Lay the strips facedown on a piece of cardboard and coat with spray adhesive.
steps.visual_description: Paint chip strips laid out on cardboard, ready for adhesive.

steps.instruction: Apply the strips to the tabletop one by one until your pattern is complete.
steps.visual_description: Applying paint chip strips to the tabletop.

steps.instruction: Let dry, and then trim excess using scissors or a crafts knife.
steps.visual_description: Trimming excess paint chip strips from the edge of the tabletop.

steps.instruction: Seal with a couple of coats of polycrylic clear glossy spray.
steps.visual_description: Spraying the tabletop with a clear sealant.

steps.instruction: For extra protection, top your table with a piece of glass cut to its dimensions.
steps.visual_description: A clear glass top placed over the finished paint chip tabletop.

projects.finished_product_description: A bedside table with a colorful, geometric pattern on its tabletop, created from paint chips.

diagram_descriptions: Above: A close-up view of a craft cutting mat with various colored paper strips, a rotary cutter, and a craft knife.
Left: A close-up view of a craft cutting mat with several colored paper strips arranged in a herringbone pattern, a rotary cutter, and a craft knife.

projects.name: Fresh frames

tools.name: square punch
tools.purpose: punching square openings for frames and creating mini magnets

tools.name: crafts knife
tools.purpose: trimming magnetic sheet around paint chip

steps.instruction: Peel away the backing on a piece of magnetic sheet.
steps.visual_description: White backing being peeled from a magnetic sheet

steps.instruction: Apply a paint chip to the exposed adhesive of the magnetic sheet.
steps.visual_description: Pink paint chip being pressed onto the magnetic sheet

steps.instruction: Trim around the paint chip with a crafts knife.
steps.visual_description: Crafts knife next to a paint chip on magnetic sheet

steps.instruction: Punch a square near the top of the combined paint chip and magnetic sheet to create a frame opening.
steps.visual_description: Green square punch tool creating an opening in a yellow paint chip/magnetic sheet combination

steps.instruction: Use the resulting magnetic frame to display your favorite photos.
steps.visual_description: Magnetic frames holding photos on a magnetic board

steps.instruction: Don't discard the punched-out squares; these can be used to make mini magnets or for the lampshade project on page 9.
steps.visual_description: Small circular punched-out pieces of paint chips

steps.instruction: For more variety, punch different shapes for magnetic frames and mini magnets.
steps.visual_description: Circular magnets on the magnetic board

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: Adhere paint chip to self-adhesive magnetic sheet, trim excess magnetic sheet, then punch a square opening near the top of the paint chip to create a photo frame. The punched-out piece can be used as a mini magnet.

tips: Don't toss the punched-out squares—these make mini magnets or use them for the lampshade project on page 9.
For more fun magnetic frames, punch different shapes.
projects.finished_product_description: Magnetic frames made from colorful paint chips with square openings for photos, displayed on a magnetic board. Also, small mini magnets created from the punched-out pieces.

diagram_descriptions: Close-up photo showing the crafting process: a green square punch tool, a pink paint chip being applied to a white self-adhesive magnetic sheet with its backing peeled, a black crafts knife, and a finished yellow paint chip frame with a square opening. Small orange and pink circular punched-out pieces are also visible.

Full shot of a white magnetic board adorned with various items. Several magnetic frames made from yellow, orange, and pink paint chips display photos. Blue and red circular magnets hold up tickets and other papers. A white Starbucks cup sits on a white shelf below, next to a metal mesh organizer. An orange gift bag with white tissue paper and a set of keys hanging on a white hook are also visible on the shelf.
Circular inset highlighting a pink magnetic frame with a child's photo, labeled 'GLR09' and 'Watermelon Smoo' (likely 'Smooth').

steps.instruction: Round the corners of the flooring samples by tracing around the paint chips' corners and carefully trimming excess material with scissors.

steps.instruction: In a well-ventilated area, apply five coats of a glossy polycrylic sealer, being sure to allow full drying time between coats.

steps.instruction: Affix felt pads to the coaster bottoms to prevent scuffing.

projects.name: Something to cluck about (Charming Chicken Coop)

materials.details: for siding, salvaged from an old barn and run-down fences
for sloped roof, left over from a roofing project

steps.instruction: Build a charming chicken coop (henhouse) on a base of concrete posts using basic 2x4 framing. Utilize reclaimed materials, such as lumber from old barns and fences for siding, and leftover roofing shingles for a sloped roof, to keep costs low and enhance country charm. This specific coop was built by TV show host Michele Beschen in one weekend for approximately $50.

tips: Check local zoning for livestock ordinances and permit requirements before you build.
projects.finished_product_description: A charming, rustic chicken coop (henhouse) built in one weekend for approximately $50, featuring a base of concrete posts, basic 2x4 framing, and reclaimed materials for siding and a sloped roof.

In front of the coop, a red wheelbarrow filled with various plants (some with red/purple leaves) is next to a bale of hay.

A photo of a woman named Michele Beschen, wearing a hat and a green t-shirt, holding a small chicken. She is smiling and pointing at something off-camera. A young girl in a yellow tank top is standing next to her, also holding a small chicken.

tools_reference.name: Paint Roller
tools_reference.use: Spreads paint about three times as much as a brush in the same amount of time. Use a 3/16- or 1/4-inch nap made of foam or polyester for gloss latex paint on a smooth wall. A 3/8- to 1/2-inch nap works best for rolling flat, satin, and semigloss paints on smooth to lightly textured walls, while a 3/4-inch nap tackles rough surfaces such as stucco walls or popcorn ceilings. Always use lamb's wool rollers when applying oil-base paints and stains.

tools_reference.name: Paint Brush
tools_reference.use: A 3-inch brush is the workhorse for painting large areas and for outlining walls or ceilings and cutting in to corners. Choose a 2-inch angled brush for painting door and window frames, moldings, and other areas where you need control. Use a 1-inch brush to paint furnishings and accents. Broad, short-bristle brushes are best for applying stains.

tools_reference.name: Paint Sprayer
tools_reference.use: Requires more prep work and clean up than rollers and brushes but is the ideal tool for exterior painting and large areas. Sprayers cover a wide swath quickly and lay a smooth coat over distressed surfaces. For small jobs such as painting furnishings, canned spray paint may be your best option.

steps.instruction: Pour 2 inches of water in a shallow container larger than your biggest piece.

Use a toothpick to combine colors organically.
Lightly dip the surface of your piece onto the polish and lift straight up.
Pour in fresh polish for each drawer front.
Let them dry for at least 24 hours.

tips: Use new polish, as polish from old or opened bottles tends to congeal.
Work quickly, as nail polish is designed to dry in minutes.

projects.name: Marbled Paper

materials.dimensions: at least 2 inches larger than your paper

steps.instruction: Gather materials (a). Add water 1 cup at a time to a depth of 2 inches. Mix in 1 tablespoon of alum per 1 cup of water (b).
steps.visual_description: Image a shows various supplies including pans, bottles of paint, alum, spoons, and clothespins. Image b shows alum being sprinkled into a pan of water.

steps.instruction: Submerge paper in the alum solution. (Alternatively, you can use a paintbrush or sponge to paint the alum mixture onto your paper.) Rinse lightly and let dry. Use an iron on the lowest heat setting to remove wrinkles from the paper.
steps.visual_description: Image d shows a hand holding paper and submerging it into a pan with a marbled pattern.

steps.instruction: Use water to dilute the acrylic paint by 50 percent. Repeat this process for all your colors. Tip: Remove half of the paint from a paint squeeze bottle and replace it with water. This makes it easy to apply the paint in the next steps.
steps.visual_description: Image c shows paint being squeezed from a bottle into a pan of water with a marbled pattern.

steps.instruction: In a separate pan add at least 2 inches of liquid starch. Test the weight of the paint by squeezing a tiny drop of diluted paint into the starch. If it sinks, dilute the paint further. If it floats, proceed to Step 5.
Squeeze diluted paint in a swirly, random pattern onto the surface of the starch (c). Add other colors; use a toothpick to swirl (d).
steps.visual_description: Image c shows paint being squeezed into the starch. Image d shows a toothpick being used to swirl the paint.

steps.instruction: Gently place paper on the paint for 8-10 seconds (e). Carefully lift the paper by one edge from the water. If desired, use tweezers. Try not to shift the paper or remove it quickly as the pattern could smear.
steps.visual_description: Image e shows paper being gently placed onto the marbled paint surface.

steps.instruction: Hang the paper from a hanger using clothespins (f). Dry for several hours.
steps.visual_description: Image f shows a marbled paper hanging from a clothes hanger with clothespins.

tips: Remove half of the paint from a paint squeeze bottle and replace it with water. This makes it easy to apply the paint in the next steps.
Try not to shift the paper or remove it quickly as the pattern could smear.
projects.finished_product_description: A sheet of paper with a unique marbled pattern.

projects.name: Geometric Wall Stamp

steps.instruction: Gather materials (a). Draw four identical shapes on the crafts foam using a pen and straightedge. Cut out shapes with a utility knife or scissors. We used diamonds, but you could use any simple, repeatable shape.
steps.visual_description: Photo (a) shows various craft supplies including cans of paint, a bottle of glaze, foam sheets, a paper towel roll, and a plate with cut-out diamond shapes.

steps.instruction: If you're concerned about keeping your design on a grid, use a level, straightedge, and pencil to draw a few light guidelines on the wall every 12-18 inches.
steps.visual_description: Photo (b) shows hands wearing blue gloves pouring paint onto plates and adding glaze.

steps.instruction: Set out plates on a covered work surface. On a plate pour about 3 tablespoons of paint (one color per plate). Add 1 tablespoon of mixing glaze to each plate. Use sponge brushes to mix the paint and glaze (b).
steps.visual_description: Photo (c) shows hands wearing blue gloves holding a foam shape and a sponge brush, applying paint to the foam shape.

steps.instruction: Set a foam shape on a paper towel. Moisten a sponge brush with water, dip it in the paint mixture, and brush on one side of a foam shape (c). Brush all strokes in the same direction.
steps.visual_description: Photo (d) shows hands wearing blue gloves pressing a painted foam shape onto a surface, likely a test piece of poster board.

steps.instruction: Wipe excess paint off the edge of the shape with a wet paper towel, then turn it over and press the shape onto the wall, making sure all parts of the shape contact the surface (d).
steps.visual_description: Photo (e) shows hands wearing blue gloves holding a foam shape and pressing it onto a wall, overlapping a previously stamped shape.

steps.instruction: Repeat Steps 4 and 5 using another foam shape and paint color. Press the shape onto the wall (we used a piece of poster board to test our pattern first), overlapping a portion of the previously stamped shape (e).
steps.visual_description: Photo (f) shows a section of a wall with several geometric shapes stamped in different colors, creating a pattern. Some shapes overlap.

steps.instruction: Load each shape with a different color, and continue stamping and layering shapes (f) until your design is complete.
steps.visual_description: Photo (f) shows a section of a wall with several geometric shapes stamped in different colors, creating a pattern. Some shapes overlap.

projects.finished_product_description: A geometric pattern on a wall created by stamping repeatable shapes in different colors.

diagram_descriptions: Photo (a) shows various craft supplies including cans of paint, a bottle of glaze, foam sheets, a paper towel roll, and a plate with cut-out diamond shapes.

projects.name: Chalked Wall

steps.instruction: Gather supplies (a). Prime and paint the wall according to the directions on the chalkboard paint can.
steps.visual_description: Image (a) shows a can of chalkboard paint, a roller, and a rag.

steps.instruction: Scribble chalk across the painted surface, then erase using rags or a chalkboard eraser (b). This gives your final design a uniform surface and prevents "ghosts" if you change the design later.
steps.visual_description: Image (b) shows a hand erasing chalk scribbles from a chalkboard surface with a rag.

steps.instruction: Create a paper pattern of your design (c). Transfer it to cardboard with pencil, and cut it out (d).
steps.visual_description: Image (c) shows a hand drawing a quatrefoil shape on paper. Image (d) shows a pencil tracing a quatrefoil shape onto cardboard with scissors nearby.

steps.instruction: Tape a small level to the pattern (e) to maintain a straight repeat of the design. Have a carpenter's square handy also.
steps.visual_description: Image (e) shows a quatrefoil cardboard cutout taped to a surface with a small level attached to its edge.

steps.instruction: Trace your design on the wall with chalk (f), starting at the center and working outward.
steps.visual_description: Image (f) shows a hand holding chalk to trace a quatrefoil pattern onto a chalkboard wall.

tips: For Resources see page 106.
projects.finished_product_description: A wall painted with chalkboard paint, featuring a repeating quatrefoil design drawn in chalk.

steps.instruction: Apply thinned white oil-base paint and Spanish oak stain to a new table.
steps.visual_description: A table with a dark, aged wood finish.

tips: Oil-base paint is the better choice over quick-drying latex paint for a satin feel.
Oil-base paint applies smoothly and pairs well with wood.

projects.name: Wood Carved Rose Design

steps.instruction: Using a simple, sharp wood-carving tool, create foot-long rose carvings on the wood surface (tabletop or table legs). Make vertical strokes with the tool, following the grain of the wood to prevent splintering. Ensure grooves are shallow, just deep enough to reveal the raw wood.
steps.visual_description: Carved rose design on wood showing lighter raw wood in grooves.

steps.instruction: Rub thinned paint into the carved grooves to make the design stand out.
steps.visual_description: Paint being applied to carved grooves.

steps.instruction: If paint builds up around the design, use a soft cloth to work it into the wood until it blends in.
steps.visual_description: Soft cloth used to blend excess paint into wood.

tips: Follow the wood grain when carving to prevent splintering.
Ensure grooves are shallow, just deep enough to reveal raw wood.
Work excess paint into the wood with a soft cloth for a blended finish.
projects.finished_product_description: A wooden surface (tabletop or table legs) adorned with foot-long rose carvings, where thinned paint has been rubbed into the grooves to highlight the design and blend seamlessly with the wood.

diagram_descriptions: Close-up photo of a dark brown wooden surface featuring a carved rose design. The carving reveals lighter, natural wood underneath, forming a textured pattern of short, vertical lines for the petals and stem. A white plate holding a slice of white cake with frosting, and a folded floral-patterned napkin (with an orange border and yellow and red flowers), are partially visible in the upper left corner of the image.

projects.name: DIY Oak-Veneered Dining Table

steps.instruction: Mix 1/2 cup white paint and 1/2 cup turpentine in a small container. That will be enough to cover a 38-inch square tabletop. Rub into the surface of the table with a soft rag (a). The paint mixture soaks into the wood, leaving no wipe marks.
steps.visual_description: Image (a) shows a hand rubbing a white mixture onto a wooden surface with a rag.

steps.instruction: While the paint is still wet, wipe on the wood stain. The white grain should show through (b). Spanish oak is a very dark stain color, so you won't need much.
steps.visual_description: Image (b) shows a hand wiping a dark stain onto a wet, painted wooden surface, revealing white grain.

steps.instruction: When the stain is dry (wait at least six hours), use a sharp wood chisel to make vertical strokes in the surface to carve a design (c). Follow the wood grain when you make your strokes. (Going against the grain splinters the veneer.) Keep the design shallow so food and debris don't get stuck in the grooves. Carve just deep enough to reveal raw wood.
steps.visual_description: Image (c) shows a wood chisel carving vertical lines into a stained wooden surface, following the grain.

steps.instruction: Rub a small amount of the thinned paint into the grooves (d), wipe off excess.
steps.visual_description: Image (d) shows a hand wiping excess thinned paint from carved grooves on a wooden surface.

steps.instruction: Repeat Steps 3 and 4 to add your design to the table legs.

tips: Going against the grain splinters the veneer.
Keep the design shallow so food and debris don't get stuck in the grooves.
Carve just deep enough to reveal raw wood.
projects.finished_product_description: An oak-veneered dining table with a wash effect and carved designs on the surface and legs.

diagram_descriptions: A large image of a wooden dining table with a distinctive leg structure.

projects.name: Pop-Modern Table Makeover

steps.instruction: To complete this pop-modern look of canary and hot pink stripes over a solid white table, we used a fun decorative tape called washi (available online in a variety of colors and patterns from sites such as cutetape.com).
steps.visual_description: A white table surface is covered with alternating stripes of canary yellow and hot pink decorative tape.

steps.instruction: You can easily change this inexpensive treatment—simply peel away the tape and start over.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of the table surface showing the striped pattern created by the washi tape.

tips: Simply peel away the tape and start over to change the look.
projects.finished_product_description: A white table surface decorated with colorful striped washi tape.

diagram_descriptions: A white table is covered with alternating stripes of canary yellow and hot pink decorative tape, creating a pop-modern look. A glass with a lemon slice and a pink straw sits on the table, along with a bowl of lemons. The legs of the table are also decorated with vertical stripes of yellow and pink tape.

projects.name: How to Apply a Washi Tape Treatment

steps.instruction: Cover the table with one coat of white paint. One coat will look solid white but allow a bit of the grain to show.
steps.visual_description: A paintbrush applying white paint to a wooden surface.

steps.instruction: When dry (wait about an afternoon), add washi tape. We applied vertical stripes first, carrying the striping over the top (b) in an off-center design that continues over the lip of the table then down the legs.
steps.visual_description: Pink washi tape being applied vertically to a surface, with some tape extending over an edge.

steps.instruction: To create a herringbone pattern, mark a center point for the design and lay strips of tape at a slight angle along each side. Allow 1/4 inch between each strip. Overlap the tape slightly at the center point.
steps.visual_description: A herringbone pattern created with pink and yellow washi tape on a white surface. A ruler and pencil are used to mark a center line.

steps.instruction: Trim the tape ends 1/4 inch to the right of the center line with a sharp crafts knife and metal ruler. Slice through just the tape layer, using a light touch so you don't mar the tabletop (d). Repeat the cut 1/4 inch to the left of the center and peel away the small trimmed ends (e).
steps.visual_description: A crafts knife and ruler are used to trim washi tape. Another image shows the trimmed tape being peeled away.

projects.finished_product_description: A table with a striped and herringbone pattern created with pink and yellow washi tape.

diagram_descriptions: Image a: A paintbrush applying white paint to a wooden surface.
Image b: Pink washi tape being applied vertically to a surface, with some tape extending over an edge.
Image c: A herringbone pattern created with pink and yellow washi tape on a white surface.
Image d: A ruler and pencil are used to mark a center line and trim washi tape.
Image e: Trimmed washi tape ends being peeled away.

projects.name: How to transfer a design using encaustic medium

materials.details: unfinished or with encaustic color applied
from art supply store such as rfpaints.com
must be from a copy machine that uses toner

steps.instruction: Gather materials (a). Apply a layer of heated encaustic medium to the area to be embellished (see Step 2, opposite).
steps.visual_description: Image a shows a spoon applying heated encaustic medium to a photocopied butterfly design.

steps.instruction: Place the image facedown on the table. (The encaustic medium beneath will be warm to the touch.)
steps.visual_description: Image b shows a hand placing a photocopied butterfly design, face down, onto a surface.

steps.instruction: Burnish the paper with the back of a spoon using a lot of pressure (b).
steps.visual_description: Image c shows a hand rubbing the back of the paper with a finger, likely to burnish.

steps.instruction: Sprinkle water over the paper, and rub very gently with your fingers (c). The paper will fall away while the image remains (d). Set the transfer using a heat gun (see Step 3, opposite).
steps.visual_description: Image d shows a completed butterfly transfer on the surface.

projects.finished_product_description: A table with a transferred butterfly design on its surface, sealed with encaustic medium. The table legs are painted blue. A vase of flowers and a cheese board are on the table.

diagram_descriptions: Four small images labeled a, b, c, and d showing the steps of transferring a design using encaustic medium.
A large image of a wooden table with a blue base, decorated with a transferred butterfly design and a cross-stitch pattern. A vase of flowers and a cheese board with crackers are on the table.
Text box titled 'What we did...' describing the encaustic painting technique used on the table and the transfer of a butterfly design.

projects.name: how to apply encaustic color

materials.color: Cadmium Lemon, Cobalt Green, and Manganese Blue Hue

tools.name: Electric griddle
tools.purpose: heat encaustic medium (alternative to heating palette)

tools.name: Clothespins
tools.purpose: create a handle for soup cans

tools.name: Smoothing/scraping tool
tools.purpose: smooth medium into surface, scrape wax

tools.name: Crafts heat gun
tools.purpose: smooth medium, keep wax malleable, set color, fuse layers

steps.instruction: Gather your materials. To get a bit of color on the table quickly, scribble the encaustic green block (a, shown with other colors and encaustic medium) liberally across the unfinished tabletop (b).
steps.visual_description: Photo (a) shows three encaustic color blocks (yellow, blue, green) and white wax flakes. Photo (b) shows a hand scribbling a green encaustic block onto a light wood tabletop, leaving green wax marks.

steps.instruction: Using the heating palette or electric griddle, heat the encaustic medium in a soup can until the medium is liquid, about 180 degrees F. Clip a clothespin "handle" to the can. Be careful: The can will be hot. Pour the medium over a section of the table (c).
steps.visual_description: Photo (c) shows a hand holding a soup can with a clothespin handle, pouring a clear liquid (encaustic medium) onto a light wood surface.

steps.instruction: Work quickly using the smoothing tool and heat gun to smooth the medium into the surface (d). The wax-base medium will start to harden on the tool (e). The wax and the color will blend into the grain of the wood as you scrape along the surface (f). Use one hand to spread with the scraping tool; hold the heat gun with the other hand to keep everything malleable (g).
steps.visual_description: Photo (d) shows a hand pressing a black smoothing tool onto a wood surface with green wax. Photo (e) shows the black smoothing tool with hardened green wax on its edge. Photo (f) shows a section of the wood surface after scraping, with green wax blended into the wood grain. Photo (g) shows a hand holding a white heat gun, directing heat onto the wood surface with green wax.

steps.instruction: Heat a slice of each color in separate soup cans. Dip a brush into the color and apply to the tabletop (h). Use the heat gun to set the color into the layer beneath. (Every time you add color, use a heat gun to fuse it to the layer beneath.) We used blue and yellow for the flower and green for the stem (i).
steps.visual_description: Photo (h) shows a hand holding a brush, applying blue encaustic color in an 'X' shape onto the wood surface, next to another 'X' shape. Photo (i) shows a finished design on the wood surface, depicting a flower with blue petals, a yellow center, and a green stem, all made with encaustic colors.

projects.finished_product_description: A tabletop decorated with encaustic colors, featuring a flower design with blue petals, a yellow center, and a green stem.

projects.name: Frosted Glass Vases

materials.item: Krylon Frosted Glass Finish spray paint

steps.instruction: Cut strips of tape 1-6 inches long. Secure them to the vase starting each strip at the bottom and running it vertically. Angle strips slightly for desired affect.

steps.instruction: To mask the other vase, wind the tape around it, crisscrossing a few times and adding a few bee stickers.

steps.instruction: Once your vases are masked, spray with the frost paint following manufacturer's directions. Let dry completely, then remove tape.

projects.name: Cork Trivet

steps.instruction: Measure and mark corks into 1/2-inch sections (or take your chances and eyeball it). Place corks on a cutting board, and carefully cut at each mark.
steps.visual_description: A hand holding a serrated knife cutting a wine cork into 1/2-inch sections on a wooden cutting board. The cork is marked with a pencil.

steps.instruction: Hot-glue corks together, starting with one in the center and circling around it to make a flower shape; continue until reaching desired size. Be conscious of placing the best side of each cork to the side that will be the top, and making sure that side is also the flattest or most even overall.
steps.visual_description: A hand holding a hot glue gun attaching wine corks together in a circular, flower-like pattern. The corks are arranged with their best sides facing up.

steps.instruction: Paint the cork tops as desired using crafts paints. When dry, top with a clear sealer, if desired.
steps.visual_description: A close-up of a cork trivet with the tops of the corks painted in light blue. A paintbrush is shown applying paint.

steps.instruction: Print four sets of shapes onto sticker paper. Cut out shapes and remove backing.

steps.instruction: Apply the masks to a stained tabletop (a) and roll with brayer. Prime and paint the table.

projects.name: How to Stamp with Celery

steps.instruction: To make the stamp, cut celery 2-3 inches from the end (a), then wrap tape around end to hold together. Let dry for 20 minutes.
steps.visual_description: Image (a) shows a hand cutting celery with a knife on a cutting board. Image (b) shows a piece of celery with tape wrapped around one end, resembling a stamp.

steps.instruction: Pour paint onto a paper plate, and use the paintbrush to apply paint to the celery ends. Avoid dripping paint into the stalks.
steps.visual_description: Image (b) shows a hand holding the celery stamp over a fabric-covered surface with rose patterns.

steps.instruction: Firmly press the stamp onto the fabric-covered seat (b). Remove the stamp without sliding it. Repeat in your desired arrangement. Let dry.
steps.visual_description: Image (b) shows a hand pressing the celery stamp onto a fabric-covered seat.

steps.instruction: Dip style stick into paint, roll off excess, and paint on leaves as desired (c). Let dry.
steps.visual_description: Image (c) shows a hand using a style stick to paint leaves onto the fabric, next to a stamped rose.

projects.name: Starburst Mirror

steps.instruction: Make your own starburst mirror in an afternoon following Myquillyn's instructions.
steps.visual_description: A large white paper starburst with a dark circular mirror in the center, mounted on a grey wall. The number '1' is overlaid on the bottom left of the image.

tips: Go to her blog, thenester.com, and search "$20 sunburst mirror".

projects.name: Slipcovers

steps.instruction: Get the look of custom slipcovers delivered to your door. Natural cotton duck suits the clean cottage look, but you'll readily find patterns should you prefer.
steps.visual_description: A light-colored sofa covered with a slipcover. The slipcover has a textured appearance and fits snugly over the sofa's arms and cushions. The number '2' is overlaid on the bottom left of the image.

projects.name: Plate Hangers

steps.instruction: Safely hang plates by choosing hangers based on their size and weight. And plate hangers are as inexpensive as third-wave ceramic ware.
steps.visual_description: A package of 'Hang it up with Moore Plate Hanger' in size Large. The package shows a gold-colored wire hanger. The number '3' is overlaid on the bottom left of the image.

tips: Heavy-duty hanger, $3.29; joann.com

projects.name: Chalkboard Con-Tact Paper

steps.instruction: As easy as chalkboard paint, chalkboard Con-Tact paper allows you to create a writeable surface anywhere you can adhere paper.
steps.visual_description: A roll of black Con-Tact paper, partially unrolled, showing a grid pattern on the back. The number '4' is overlaid on the bottom left of the image.

projects.name: Numbered Stair Risers

steps.instruction: Mask the treads using painter's tape.
steps.visual_description: Stairs with painter's tape covering the treads.

steps.instruction: Paint the risers your desired color.
steps.visual_description: Stairs with painted risers.

steps.instruction: Remove the tape before the paint is completely dry.
steps.visual_description: Stairs with painted risers and removed tape.

steps.instruction: When the risers are dry, measure to find the center of each step horizontally and vertically.
steps.visual_description: Stairs with center marks on the risers.

steps.instruction: Mark lightly with a pencil.
steps.visual_description: Stairs with light pencil marks on the risers.

steps.instruction: Adhere the decals according to supplier's instructions.
steps.visual_description: Stairs with numbered decals applied to the risers.

steps.instruction: If desired, finish with a clear sealer to protect the decals from foot traffic.
steps.visual_description: Stairs with numbered decals and a clear sealer applied.

tips: Decals scored for $24 on twistmo.etsy.com
projects.finished_product_description: Stair risers decorated with large, teal numbers (5, 4, 3, 2, 1).

diagram_descriptions: A set of stairs with white risers and dark wood treads. Large teal numbers (5, 4, 3, 2, 1) are adhered to the risers in descending order from top to bottom. A stack of books is on the top step. A white door with glass panes is to the left of the stairs. Red brick is to the right of the stairs.

projects.name: Wallpapered Stair Risers

steps.instruction: Prime painted risers using a wallpaper primer as needed.
Cut wallpaper slightly wider and longer than the actual risers.
Adhere wallpaper to the risers just as you would to a wall, according to the supplier's instructions.
Use a straightedge and utility knife to trim any excess paper.
When dry, top the wallpaper with a wallpaper sealer to protect the paper.

projects.finished_product_description: A flight of stairs with risers decorated in a collage of various green-toned Galbraith & Paul wallpaper patterns, protected by a sealer.

diagram_descriptions: A full-page photo of a staircase with multiple risers decorated with a collage of different green-patterned wallpapers. A small child with red hair, wearing a red polka-dot dress, is walking up the stairs, holding onto the white banister. The stair treads are dark wood, and the banister and newel post are white. The wallpaper patterns include various geometric designs, floral motifs, and a pattern featuring blue birds and tree branches.

projects.name: Colorful Stair Riser Makeover

steps.instruction: Mask each tread with painter's tape.
steps.visual_description: Implied by the clean lines between treads and risers in the finished photo.

steps.instruction: Starting at the top step and working down, use a small roller or 2-inch brush to paint each riser your desired color.
steps.visual_description: Stair risers painted in alternating colors (coral, light green, yellow, light blue, red).

steps.instruction: Remove the tape before paint is completely dry.
steps.visual_description: Not explicitly shown, but implied by the finished look.

steps.instruction: Alternatively, paint all risers the same color and use a contrasting color to paint a faux runner up the stairs, covering both the risers and treads.
steps.visual_description: Not shown in the image, described as an alternative method.

tips: Be sure to use similar paint finishes—ours are semigloss.
projects.finished_product_description: A staircase with dark stained wood treads and risers painted in a vibrant, alternating color scheme including coral, light green, yellow, light blue, and red. A brown and white Cavalier King Charles Spaniel dog is sitting on one of the steps.

diagram_descriptions: A full-page photograph of a staircase with dark stained wood treads and risers painted in a sequence of bright, solid colors: coral, light green, yellow, light blue, and red. A brown and white Cavalier King Charles Spaniel dog is sitting on the light green riser, looking towards the left side of the frame.

projects.name: Fluttery Decals Staircase

steps.instruction: Mask treads using painter's tape.
Paint the risers your desired color. Remove tape before the paint is completely dry.
Measure the risers, and cut decals to size as needed.
Adhere decals according to the supplier's instructions.
If desired, finish with a clear sealer to protect the decals.

tips: Custom-ordered decals from janeymacwalls.etsy.com for $40.
projects.finished_product_description: A staircase with white risers decorated with yellow-green butterflies and reeds, and one orange bird decal. The bottom risers have a green grass-like decal pattern.

diagram_descriptions: A close-up view of a staircase with wooden treads and white risers. The risers are decorated with decals of yellow-green butterflies, reeds, and grass. One riser features an orange bird decal.
A close-up view of the bottom portion of the staircase, showing the green painted risers with white grass-like decals.
A close-up view of the top portion of the staircase, showing wooden treads and white risers with yellow-green butterfly decals.
A text box titled 'What we did...' explaining the process of decorating the staircase with decals.

projects.name: Stenciled Stair Risers

steps.instruction: Mask the risers using painter's tape.
steps.visual_description: Stair risers masked with painter's tape.

steps.instruction: Paint a base coat (ours is white).
steps.visual_description: Stair risers painted with a white base coat.

steps.instruction: When the paint is dry, spray the stencil back with stencil adhesive and secure it to the top riser.
steps.visual_description: Zebra-pattern stencil adhered to a stair riser.

steps.instruction: Use a stencil brush and paint (we used coral) to apply the pattern.
steps.visual_description: Applying coral paint through the zebra stencil onto a stair riser.

steps.instruction: Remove the stencil and repeat on each step.
steps.visual_description: Removing stencil to reveal pattern on a stair riser.

steps.instruction: Carefully pull off the tape, and finish the risers with a clear sealer for protection.
steps.visual_description: Stair risers with finished zebra pattern and clear sealer.

tips: Walk on the wild side by stenciling risers with an animal print in an unexpected hue.
projects.finished_product_description: Stair risers decorated with a white base coat and an orange zebra-pattern stencil.

diagram_descriptions: A woman in a teal and cream dress and red and blue platform heels is sitting on a wooden staircase with orange and white zebra-patterned risers.

projects.name: A wash in memories

steps.instruction: Convert a digital photo to black and white, then print it on lightweight watercolor paper or cardstock. Avoid ink-jet printers!
steps.visual_description: A watercolor paint palette with many colors and a black and white photo of a girl with a yellow dress and pink boots holding an umbrella, placed on a wooden surface next to a glass with pink liquid.

steps.instruction: Tint your favorite details from the image with watercolor paints (light colors work best) using a soft watercolor brush.
Leave the remainder of the photo black and white, and allow it to dry at least three hours.
If the first wash of color isn't bright enough, apply a second coat.
Let dry completely before framing.

projects.finished_product_description: A framed watercolor-tinted black and white photograph of a girl.

diagram_descriptions: A framed photograph of a young girl in a yellow dress and pink boots holding a green umbrella, standing in a natural setting. The photo is partially tinted with watercolor.

projects.name: Light waves lampshade

steps.instruction: Moisten a large paintbrush with water, and sweep a wavelike pattern around the bottom of the shade.
steps.visual_description: A wavelike pattern is applied around the bottom edge of a lampshade.

steps.instruction: Tap wet paint into the pattern with a soft round watercolor brush.
steps.visual_description: Paint is being tapped into the wet wavelike pattern on the lampshade.

steps.instruction: After the paint dries, dot the wave with more paint in alternating colors.
steps.visual_description: Dots of paint are being added to the dried wave pattern in alternating colors.

steps.instruction: For dots that blend, paint them with edges touching.
steps.visual_description: Dots of paint are applied with their edges touching to create a blended effect.

tips: Use watercolor paint for paper lampshades, and fabric paint for fabric shades.
projects.finished_product_description: A lampshade with a decorative watercolor-style wave pattern at the bottom in shades of green, yellow, and blue.

diagram_descriptions: A close-up of a white lampshade with a colorful, wavy watercolor-style pattern applied to the bottom edge. The pattern features blended splotches of green, yellow, and blue. The lampshade is on a teal glass lamp base. In the background is a wooden surface. To the right of the lamp is a green ceramic lotus-shaped bowl and two stacked books, with a piece of driftwood in front of them.

projects.name: Stripes ahoy Napkins

steps.instruction: Combine fabric paint and water until the mixture achieves a watery consistency.
steps.visual_description: A small white bowl with blue liquid, a bottle of blue fabric paint, and a paintbrush.

steps.instruction: Paint stripes across the napkins using a flat brush.
steps.visual_description: A hand holding a paintbrush and painting blue stripes on a white napkin.

steps.instruction: For thinner stripes than those seen here, use a round brush.
steps.visual_description: A hand holding a paintbrush and painting blue stripes on a white napkin.

steps.instruction: The color should bleed slightly to achieve a watercolor-like appearance once the paint dries.
steps.visual_description: A hand holding a paintbrush and painting blue stripes on a white napkin.

tips: The color should bleed slightly to achieve a watercolor-like appearance once the paint dries.
projects.finished_product_description: A set of napkins with blue watercolor-like stripes, tied with an orange fabric flower.

diagram_descriptions: A close-up of a table setting with a blue and white plate, a woven placemat, and a white napkin with blue stripes tied with an orange fabric flower.
A close-up of a hand painting blue stripes on a white napkin with a paintbrush. A small bowl of blue paint mixture and a bottle of fabric paint are visible.

projects.name: Watered down duvet

steps.instruction: Turn a plain duvet into a piece of art while channeling your inner Jackson Pollock.
steps.visual_description: A duvet with a splatter paint design.

steps.instruction: Wet the duvet with water, then spread it out on a flat surface (we took ours into the backyard).
steps.visual_description: A wet duvet spread out on a flat surface.

steps.instruction: Mix water and fabric paint until the combination becomes watery.
steps.visual_description: A watery mixture of paint and water.

steps.instruction: Drench a large paintbrush with the mixture and fling it at the duvet, allowing the paint to run and bleed.
steps.visual_description: Paint splatters and drips on the duvet.

steps.instruction: The colors will lightly bleed through to the back layer of fabric.
steps.visual_description: Paint bleeding through the fabric.

steps.instruction: After the duvet has dried, use a bottle fitted with a tip that has a small opening and filled with the water-paint mixture to paint circles, lines, and dots.
steps.visual_description: Circles, lines, and dots painted on the duvet with a bottle.

steps.instruction: The paint may bleed slightly but will hold its form on the dry duvet.
steps.visual_description: Paint details on the dry duvet.

steps.instruction: Repeat with pillow shams.
steps.visual_description: Pillow shams with similar paint designs.

steps.instruction: Follow manufacturer's instructions to permanently set the paint.
steps.visual_description: A finished duvet and pillow shams with a watered-down paint design.

projects.finished_product_description: A duvet and pillow shams with a unique, watered-down paint design featuring splatters, drips, circles, lines, and dots.

diagram_descriptions: A close-up of a bed with a duvet and pillow shams decorated with a blue and white watered-down paint design. The design includes splatters, drips, and concentric circles. A pillow with a yellow fish stencil is also visible.

projects.name: Gone Fishing Pillow Sham

steps.instruction: Float a bright fish on a pillow sham to embellish an aquatic bedroom theme.
steps.visual_description: A white pillow sham with a large orange fish design on it, with blue watercolor-like splatters around the fish.

steps.instruction: Make a fish pattern from clip art or a freehand sketch. Outline with a bold black marker.
steps.visual_description: A close-up of a white fabric with a fish outline drawn in black marker, and a bottle of Elmer's washable glue being applied to the outline.

steps.instruction: Trace it on the fabric with Elmer's washable glue (a) to create a mask. After the glue dries (it will turn white), brush on the color using a slightly watered-down fabric paint (b).
steps.visual_description: Two images: (a) shows a fish outline being traced with glue. (b) shows a close-up of the fish design on the fabric, with orange fabric paint being brushed onto the areas within the glue outline. A small bowl of orange paint and a bottle of fabric paint are visible.

steps.instruction: Once the paint dries completely, soak the sham in water and gently rub away the glue. To set your design, follow the fabric paint directions (we had to iron ours), but not before removing the glue!
steps.visual_description: The finished pillow sham with a bright orange fish design, surrounded by blue splatters.

tips: We had to iron ours, but not before removing the glue!
projects.finished_product_description: A pillow sham embellished with a painted fish design.

diagram_descriptions: Image (a) shows a hand tracing a fish outline on fabric with a bottle of Elmer's washable glue.
Image (b) shows a close-up of the fish design on fabric, with orange fabric paint being applied within the glue outline. A small bowl of orange paint and a bottle of fabric paint are visible.
The main image shows a finished pillow sham with a large orange fish design and blue splatters.

projects.name: Pop Culture Bubble Prints

steps.instruction: Mix 2 tablespoons of tempera paint with 2 tablespoons of dish soap and 1/2 cup of water in a shallow bowl.
steps.visual_description: A shallow bowl with a pinkish-orange liquid mixture, with bubbles forming on the surface.

steps.instruction: Insert a drinking straw into the mixture and blow into it until the bowl's surface is covered in bubbles.
steps.visual_description: A drinking straw is inserted into the bubble mixture, with a hand holding it.

steps.instruction: Lay a piece of plain white paper across the bowl. The bubbles will pop, leaving prints on the paper.
steps.visual_description: A piece of white paper is placed on top of the bubble-covered surface in the bowl.

steps.instruction: Allow to dry and repeat with another color.
Play with the color intensity and size of the bubble prints by tweaking the paint recipe and number of bubbles to pop.
Take your dried, final work to a local copy store and enlarge the best results from your experiments.

tips: Experiment with color intensity and bubble size by adjusting the paint recipe and the number of bubbles to pop.
projects.finished_product_description: A piece of paper with abstract bubble prints in various colors, resembling a colorful, organic pattern.

Image (b) shows a hand holding a straw over a shallow bowl filled with orange bubbles, about to blow into it.
A large piece of paper with abstract bubble prints in pink, orange, and some blue splatters, hanging on a wall.

projects.name: Glass act

steps.instruction: Bring the seaside tableside by adding cool color to salvaged vases. Peruse thrift shop shelves for milky white vases in various shapes and sizes—or pour white paint into clear vases—just be sure you don't use those later for holding water!
steps.visual_description: Three vases on a wooden surface. One vase is white with green and blue squares around the neck. Another vase is white with yellow and blue streaks. A starfish is placed in front of the vases.

steps.instruction: To achieve a watercolor effect on glass, mix glass paint with a few drops of paint thinner. If desired, adjust the amount of paint thinner to achieve varying viscosities and results, such as drips and runs.
steps.visual_description: A hand holding a paintbrush with red bristles and a blue handle, applying paint to the white vase with yellow and blue streaks.

steps.instruction: Paint freehand designs on each vase using an acrylic brush (a).
steps.visual_description: Close-up of the white vase with yellow and blue streaks, showing paint being applied with a brush.

projects.finished_product_description: Decorated vases with watercolor effects, drips, and runs.

projects.name: Stenciled Lamp Base Wrap

steps.instruction: Create your own stylish stencils by searching your computer's fonts and clip art for favorite symbols to enlarge and print. (e.g., a letter O and a basic circle shape).
steps.visual_description: Computer screen showing font and clip art options

steps.instruction: Cut white kraft paper to fit around your lamp base.
steps.visual_description: Roll of kraft paper being measured against a lamp base

steps.instruction: Trace the enlarged letter O and basic circle shape onto a sheet of clear polyester film (Mylar).
steps.visual_description: Mylar sheet with traced 'O' and circle shapes

steps.instruction: Cut out the traced shapes from the Mylar with a crafts knife to create stencils.
steps.visual_description: Crafts knife cutting out a shape from Mylar

steps.instruction: Tape the 'O' stencil to the center of the kraft paper with painter's tape.
steps.visual_description: Kraft paper with an 'O' stencil taped to its center

steps.instruction: Use a stencil brush and acrylic paint to pounce paint over the 'O' stencil.
steps.visual_description: Stencil brush applying paint through the 'O' stencil

steps.instruction: Let the paint dry.
steps.visual_description: Painted 'O' shape on kraft paper

steps.instruction: Continue stenciling 'O' shapes across the paper. Spray the stencil with window cleaner and wipe clean with a paper towel between each use to prevent smudging.
steps.visual_description: Kraft paper with multiple stenciled 'O' shapes, stencil being cleaned

steps.instruction: Once the 'O' paint dries, repeat the process with the circle stencil, applying the circle directly on top of each stenciled 'O'.
steps.visual_description: Kraft paper with 'O' shapes and circle stencils being applied on top

steps.instruction: Wrap the finished stenciled paper around the lamp base and secure it at the back with tape.
steps.visual_description: Stenciled paper being wrapped around a lamp base

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: Wrap the stenciled kraft paper around the lamp base and secure the seam at the back with tape.

tips: Spray the stencil with window cleaner and wipe clean with a paper towel between each use to ensure clean lines and prevent paint buildup.
projects.finished_product_description: A modern lamp base wrapped in white kraft paper, decorated with a repeating pattern of purple 'O' shapes, each overlaid with a bright yellow circle, creating a vibrant and custom stenciled design.

templates.name: Letter O Stencil
templates.shape_description: The shape of the letter 'O', cut out from clear polyester film (Mylar).

templates.name: Basic Circle Stencil
templates.shape_description: A basic circular shape, cut out from clear polyester film (Mylar).

diagram_descriptions: A modern lamp with a white cylindrical lampshade and a rectangular metallic base. The lower part of the base is wrapped with white paper featuring a stenciled pattern of interlocking purple 'O' shapes, each with a bright yellow circle stenciled on top. The lamp is positioned on a metallic, perforated rectangular tray, which also holds an hourglass with sand and a small light blue glass vase. The background is a vibrant lime green wall.

A close-up view of the stenciled lamp base, clearly showing the repeating pattern of purple 'O' shapes intertwined, with a bright yellow circle precisely stenciled within the center of each 'O' intersection.

projects.name: Graphic Stenciled Furniture and Walls

steps.instruction: Freshen old furniture with colorful graphic stencils. Before stenciling, ready your surface by sanding, priming, and painting it. Print numbers and question marks in various sizes, trace them on clear polyester film, and cut out with a crafts knife to create your stencils. Use acrylic paint to stencil the designs on the furniture, extending some stencils beyond the edges to create a more infinite feel.
steps.visual_description: A white dresser with yellow question marks and circles stenciled on the drawers. A purple and white textured throw blanket is draped over the bottom drawer.

steps.instruction: For a wild wall treatment, type an X into your word-processing program, enlarge to desired size, print, trace onto clear polyester film, and cut out with a crafts knife. Lightly spray the back of the stencil with repositionable stencil adhesive, and position on the wall. Load your stencil brush with latex wall paint, and pounce your brush on a paper towel until mostly dry to prevent bleeding or drips. Stencil on wall with a pouncing motion. Apply several coats for an opaque finish, and carefully remove the stencil from the wall. For a relaxed look, position your stencil at different angles and vary the space between stencils.
steps.visual_description: A lime green wall with white X stencils. A green cushion and a purple and pink plaid cushion are on a green sofa, with a purple and white textured throw blanket draped over them.

projects.name: Stenciled Cabinet Doors and Coffee Table

steps.instruction: Enlarge letters and symbols from a word processor to create a variety of stencils. Draw the oblong shape freehand.
Trace each shape onto clear polyester film and cut out with a crafts knife to create a stencil.
Spray the back of the stencil with repositionable stencil adhesive and position on the cabinet door.
Lightly load your stencil brush with craft paint, lightly tap brush on paper towel to remove excess paint, and pounce the brush on the door.
Allow the paint to dry, remove the stencil, and repeat the process with other colors and symbols as desired.
Clean, prime, and paint your coffee table (if necessary).
Sketch a fun motif or download and print our zigzag stencil from BHG.com/DIYZigZagStencil.
Follow the instructions above for creating and painting a stencil using acrylic paint for the design.
